Article Title: US Patent Office answers if AI can be considered an inventor and it rejects what Biden government said
Article Text:
What Is Artificial Intelligence? Explained Simply With Real-Life Examples

AI cannot be an inventor





The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) issued new guidelines clarifying the patentability of inventions developed with the help of artificial intelligence, formally classifying generative AI systems as tools rather than creators. In a notice scheduled for publication later this week, USPTO Director John Squires established that the agency views AI software as "analogous to laboratory equipment, computer software, research databases, or any other tool that assists in the inventive process."The new guidance reportedly emphasizes that while AI can facilitate innovation, the legal credit for an invention must remain with a human. "They may provide services and generate ideas, but they remain tools used by the human inventor who conceived the claimed invention," the office stated, as per a report by Reuters. "When one natural person is involved in creating an invention with the assistance of AI, the inquiry is whether that person conceived the invention under the traditional conception standard. "While the office reiterated its previous stance that AI itself cannot be named an inventor under U.S. law, the new guidelines mark a shift in policy regarding how AI-assisted claims are evaluated. The USPTO explicitly rejected the framework utilized during former President Joe Biden’s administration.That previous approach relied on standards typically used to determine "joint inventorship" among multiple people to decide if an AI-assisted invention was patentable.Instead, the office is returning to foundational patent principles. "The same legal standard for determining inventorship applies to all inventions, regardless of whether AI systems were used in the inventive process," the office said Wednesday. "There is no separate or modified standard for AI-assisted inventions."This administrative update arrives as the legal system continues to grapple with the rise of generative technology. While U.S. courts have ruled that AI systems cannot receive patents for inventions they generate entirely on their own, they have not yet issued rulings on when a human may receive a patent for work conceived with significant AI assistance.
Article Summary: The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office issued new guidelines clarifying the patentability of inventions developed with the help of artificial intelligence. The new guidelines mark a shift in policy regarding how AI-assisted claims are evaluated. The USPTO explicitly rejected the framework utilized during former President Joe Biden’s administration.

Major Chinese technology companies are reportedly training their large AI models in data centres overseas to get around US restrictions that ban the sale of powerful Nvidia chips to China. In this way, some Chinese tech giants are bypassing US restrictions intended to slow their technological advancement, according to a report. The Financial Times, citing sources close to the matter, reported that companies such as Alibaba and TikTok parent ByteDance have been training their latest LLMs in offshore locations, primarily in data centres across Singapore and other Southeast Asian countries, for some time now. The report added that since April, when the US government banned the sale of Nvidia H20, a chip designed for the Chinese market, there has been a gradual rise in offshore training. This strategy enables Chinese companies to obtain the required computing power despite export restrictions, the report claims.In a statement to FT, a Singapore-based data centre operator said:Over the past year, Alibaba's Qwen and ByteDance's Doubao AI models have become some of the top-performing LLMs worldwide. Many developers outside China have also adopted Qwen as it is a freely availablemodel.Data centre clusters have also grown in Singapore and Malaysia, driven by Chinese demand. Many of these data centres use high-end Nvidia products, similar to those used by US Big Tech groups to train LLMs.The report cited sources familiar with the practice to suggest that Chinese companies typically sign a lease agreement to use overseas data centres owned and operated by non-Chinese entities.This follows recent changes to US export controls, after President Donald Trump removed the Biden-era “diffusion rule” earlier this year. This rule was meant to close this loophole for Chinese companies.One exception is DeepSeek, a developer of high-quality, low-cost AI models, which is being trained domestically, the report noted, citing people with knowledge of the matter. The company built up a large cluster of Nvidia chips before the US export bans took effect, the report added.It is also working closely with domestic chipmakers, led by Huawei, to develop the next generation of Chinese AI chips, the report notes.Huawei has a team of engineers stationed at DeepSeek's headquarters in Hangzhou. The company views its partnership with DeepSeek as a strategic effort to advance its semiconductor and software systems for AI training nationwide.Training LLMs requires substantial computing power to process massive datasets, leading most Chinese groups to prefer Nvidia's products for the task.However, these companies are increasingly turning to locally made Chinese chips for. This is the part when AI systems respond to a user's request, which accounts for a growing share of overall AI workloads.Beyond training, Chinese tech companies also use Southeast Asian data centres to service their overseas customers, as Alibaba and ByteDance seek to grow their share of the global cloud computing market. Chinese companies are also expanding access to data centres in other regions such as the Middle East.One constraint is that Chinese tech giants are not allowed to move private data out of the country. This means that, to customise an AI model based on specific data supplied by a local client, training must remain in China, the report mentioned, citing industry insiders.
Article Summary: Major Chinese tech companies are reportedly training their large AI models in data centres overseas. This is to get around US restrictions that ban the sale of powerful Nvidia chips to China. In this way, some Chinese tech giants are bypassing US restrictions intended to slow their technological advancement.

The corporate legal battle between global chip rivals Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) and Intel has escalated into a criminal investigation. Taiwan prosecutors have said that investigators have raided the homes of former TSMC senior vice president Wei-Jen Lo and seized digital evidence in a probe into alleged trade secret leaks. The action comes two days after TSMC filed a lawsuit against Lo, who retired from the Taiwanese chipmaker and joined Intel in October. Prosecutors stated that Lo is suspected of violating Taiwan's National Security Act.According to a report by news agency Reuters, acting on a search warrant, investigators executed searches at two of Lo's homes on Wednesday (November 26) afternoon. Prosecutors confirmed the seizure of key materials:Computers, USB drives, and other digital evidence were seized.A court also approved a petition to seize Lo’s shares and real estate pending the investigation.TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, has alleged that the movement of their former executive poses a risk to proprietary technology. The company stated earlier that there is a “high probability that Lo uses, leaks, discloses or transfers TSMC's trade secrets and confidential information to Intel.” Notably, in his role, Lo was instrumental in developing the mass production processes for TSMC’s most advanced nodes, including the 5-nanometre, 3-nm, and 2-nm chips.Intel has denied all allegations against Lo. Earlier on Thursday (November 27), Intel released a statement maintaining its full support for Lo and denying the allegations lodged by TSMC."Based on everything we know, we have no reason to believe there is any merit to the allegations involving Mr Lo," Intel said. The company also defended the move, stating that the company upholds “rigorous policies and controls” prohibiting the use of third-party confidential information.“Talent movement across companies is a common and healthy part of our industry,” Intel added..Lo's long career includes an 18-year tenure at Intel before joining TSMC in 2004 for a 21-year stint.
Article Summary: Taiwanese prosecutors have raided the homes of former TSMC senior vice president Wei-Jen Lo and seized digital evidence in a probe into alleged trade secret leaks. The action comes two days after TSMC filed a lawsuit against Lo, who retired from the Taiwanese chipmaker and joined Intel in October. Prosecutors stated that Lo is suspected of violating Taiwan's National Security Act.

Article Title: Europe okays new rules for online fraud protection and data hacking: What the ‘Payment services deal’ says
Article Text:
EU makes banks and service providers answerable to fraud and hacking







The European Union (EU) has agreed to new consumer protection measures following an agreement reached between EU member states and the European Parliament. The deal introduces new rules designed to force banks and payment service providers (PSPs) to enhance fraud prevention, eliminate hidden fees and enhance protection against data leaks. The new legislation aims to shift liability toward financial providers and online platforms.“On Thursday morning, Parliament and Council negotiators agreed on the Payment Services Regulation (PSR) and the Third Payment Services Directive (PSD3),” the European Commission said in a statement.“The regulation aims to harmonise payment services and strengthen fraud prevention across the EU. It applies to payment services provided by banks, post-office giro and payment institutions, as well as technical service providers supporting payment services, and in some cases electronic communications providers and online platforms. The directive seeks to ensure fair competition among payment service providers (PSPs), by addressing authorisation and supervisory powers, and to improve access to cash, particularly in remote areas,” it added.The core of the new rules focuses on ensuring consumers are not left responsible when security measures fail:The rules say that service providers have to offer spending limits and blocking measures to reduce the risks of fraud.This means that if a fraudster initiates or changes a transaction, “it will be treated as [an] unauthorised transaction and the PSP will be liable for the full fraudulent amount.”Moreover in case of impersonation fraud, where a scammer pretends to be a company employee and tricks the customer into approving a payment, the service provider must refund the full amount if the customer reports the fraud to the police and informs their PSP.“In addition, advertisers of financial services must show very large online platforms and search engines that they are legally allowed (or officially exempt) in the relevant country to offer those services, or that they are advertising on behalf of someone who is,” the Commission added.
Article Summary: EU agrees to new consumer protection measures following an agreement reached between EU member states and the European Parliament. The new legislation aims to shift liability toward financial providers and online platforms. The rules say that service providers have to offer spending limits and blocking measures to reduce the risks of fraud.

The Chinese tech giant's confidence appears backed by concrete results: its Qwen app exceeded 10 million downloads within a week of launching."We're not even able to keep pace with the growth in customer demand," Wu said, arguing that adoption is driven by real business needs across manufacturing and product development rather than speculation.Pichai cautioned that if an AI bubble bursts, no company would be immune, including Google itself. Drawing parallels to the dotcom era, he acknowledged that investment cycles can "overshoot" and predicted AI would follow the same pattern.The Google chief's concerns center on whether massive infrastructure spending can deliver returns quickly enough to justify current valuations. He warned about AI's "immense" energy needs, which accounted for 1.5% of global electricity consumption last year, and admitted the company faces challenges meeting its 2030 net-zero climate targets.The debate has intensified as analysts point to approximately $1.4 trillion in deals involving OpenAI, despite the company expecting revenues this year of less than one-thousandth of planned investment. Some fear a repeat of the late 1990s dotcom crash, when collapsing valuations triggered job losses and damaged pension funds.Alibaba posted $34.8 billion in revenue for its September quarter, up 5% year-over-year, though net income plummeted 53% due to heavy AI and commerce spending. The company's cloud division led growth with a 34% increase driven by AI-related products.Wu suggested the company's previously announced 380 billion yuan AI investment over three years "might be on the small side". His bullish stance notably contradicts Alibaba Chairman Joe Tsai, who warned in March about seeing "the beginning of some kind of bubble" in the rush to build data centers.The split between optimists like Wu and skeptics like Pichai reflects broader uncertainty across Silicon Valley, where Big Tech firms are expected to spend $320 billion on AI infrastructure this year while grappling with questions about when—and whether—the investments will pay off.
Article Summary: Alibaba CEO Eddie Wu dismissed concerns about an artificial intelligence bubble. Wu said the company "doesn't really see much of an issue in terms of a so-called AI bubble" Despite warnings from Google's Sundar Pichai about "elements of irrationality" in the sector.

Giving it a single sentence and a few pictures — if that’s true, if that’s what happened here — that goes against every bit of advice we have out there. It’s a nightmare scenario,” Ian Adams, an assistant criminology professor at the University of South Carolina and a member of the Council for Criminal Justice’s AI task force, was quoted as saying.“We need the specific articulated events of that event and the specific thoughts of that specific officer... That is the worst case scenario, other than explicitly telling it to make up facts,” he added.Meanwhile, Katie Kinsey, tech policy counsel at the Policing Project, noted that use of public AI tools also creates critical privacy risks. Striking similarities between two hunting stories





Apple TV has removed its upcoming French thriller "The Hunt" from its December streaming schedule following accusations that the series plagiarised a 1973 novel and its subsequent film adaptation.Production company Gaumont confirmed that the show has been shelved while it investigates claims that creator and director Cédric Anger lifted the story from Douglas Fairbairn's novel "Shoot" and the 1976 film of the same name. We take intellectual property matters very seriously."The series, starring Benoît Magimel and Mélanie Laurent, was scheduled to debut globally on December 3rd with its first two episodes. Apple has since scrubbed all promotional materials from its website, leaving the show's future uncertain.The parallels between "The Hunt" and "Shoot" appear substantial.Both stories follow a group of hunters who encounter rival hunters in the wilderness, leading to violence. In each narrative, one hunter is shot, prompting retaliation that kills an attacker. The survivors then return to civilisation, keeping the incident secret while becoming increasingly paranoid about revenge."The Hunt" follows Franck and his friends as they deal with the aftermath of their weekend hunting trip gone wrong, with Franck believing he and his companions are being tracked. Similarly, "Shoot" centers on Rex, who becomes convinced that his victim's companions will seek vengeance, even recruiting an arsenal of firepower for an anticipated confrontation.This isn't the first time Apple TV has pulled a completed series at the last minute. The streaming service postponed Jessica Chastain's "The Savant" just days before its September premiere following the shooting of rightwing activist Charlie Kirk. That show remains without a release date.

FCC urges immediate security measures for radio broadcasters







The Federal Communications Commission issued an urgent warning Wednesday after hackers infiltrated multiple US radio stations, broadcasting fake emergency alerts and obscene content to thousands of listeners across the country. The cyberattacks targeted various radio broadcasters, including ESPN 97.5 in Houston during Sunday's Dallas Cowboys game and Virginia NPR affiliate WVTF last week. The incidents involved hackers hijacking the Emergency Alert System's distinctive Attention Signal—the attention-grabbing tone typically reserved for warnings about tornadoes, hurricanes, and other disasters.The FCC identified improperly secured equipment manufactured by Swiss company Barix as the primary vulnerability. Hackers compromised studio-transmitter links, which carry programming from studios to transmitters, and reconfigured the equipment to broadcast attacker-controlled audio streams containing simulated emergency tones, obscene language, and inappropriate material.During the Houston incident, listeners heard a loop of fake emergency tones, racist content, and hacker social media promotions instead of the football broadcast.The Virginia station reported hackers exploited their backup audio system, inserting unauthorized content when the main feed experienced dead air.The agency directed broadcasters to implement basic cybersecurity protocols immediately, including changing default passwords, installing manufacturer software updates promptly, and deploying network firewalls where feasible. Stations should also continuously monitor equipment audit logs and utilize VPNs configured to restrict remote access to authorized devices only.The FCC encouraged broadcasters experiencing unauthorized access to contact equipment manufacturers and report incidents to the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center. In a 2016 statement following similar attacks, Barix emphasized its devices remain secure when properly configured with strong passwords.
Article Summary: Hackers infiltrated multiple US radio stations, broadcasting fake emergency alerts and obscene content. The FCC identified improperly secured equipment manufactured by Swiss company Barix as the primary vulnerability. Hackers compromised studio-transmitter links, which carry programming from studios to transmitters.

Article Title: Airtel tells Tata-owned Tejas Networks again: Your equipment is 'sub-standard' and don't blame it on BSNL's ...
Article Text:
What Tejas problem is as per Airtel

What Tejas said in its reply to Airtel's letter





Airtel has reportedly reiterated its stand on the equipment of Tata-owned Tejas. In a fresh escalation, Bharti Group-owned Airtel once again termed the equipment made by the Tata-owned company and deployed by state-run Bharat Sanchar Nigam Ltd (BSNL), are "sub-standard". Airtel also dismissed the local equipment maker's clarification. According to a report in Economic Times, Airtel had sent a strongly worded letter to Tejas on November 14, claiming that the issue has been affecting its Quality of Service (QoS) since December of last year. The letter reportedly expressed frustration that no corrective action has been taken despite "repeated technical submissions, discussions, joint tests, and directives." asking the latter to take immediate action on continuing interference being caused its equipment deployed by BSNL.Airtel made the comments following Tejas Networks denying claims around its equipment and instead placing the blame on Airtel for putting up sites very close to BSNL it claimed was leading to interference in the Rajasthan circle. This technical standoff occurs against the backdrop of the Indian government’s push for self-sufficiency in telecom.BSNL has been mandated to use equipment from local firms, with its 4G network being rolled out by a consortium including C-DoT, Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), and Tejas. The incident highlights the complexities of India's transition to using indigenous telecom gear, a move designed to reduce reliance on foreign vendors amid geopolitical uncertainties."The claim made by Tejas Networks is baseless. Towers have historically accommodated two or more sites of different operators without interference, so the problem isn't due to closeness of sites. The current problem is more a function of sub-standard equipment which doesn't conform to Indian spectrum allocation requirements," Airtel said in a statement to ET.The cause of the interference was due to technical non-conformance in Tejas' radio equipment and filter design. The filter supplied by Tejas was designed for 800 MHz band within frequency range of 864-894 MHz, aligned with certain international standards. However, in India, the 800 MHz downlink operates strictly between 869-889 MHz, Airtel said. "But the radio equipment made by Tejas for the 850 MHz for India - being used by BSNL - radiates signals beyond those limits, thus interfering with Airtel's 900 MHz uplink. To resolve the matter, Tejas needs to use a filter to ensure the equipment radiates signals only up to the limit," an Airtel spokesperson said.Tejas rejected the claim and instead blamed Airtel. "The interference from BSNL to Airtel arises not due to Tejas's radios not meeting out-of-band emission specifications but primarily because Airtel's sites are deployed very close to BSNL's, without adequately maximising coupling losses," Tejas replied to Airtel in a letter sent on November 24.Tejas attributed the issue to historical spectrum allocation rather than hardware failure. "The problem in Rajasthan circle is due to an overlap of spectrum bands and is being addressed by additional filtering in consultation with DoT, Airtel and BSNL," the company told ET.

Bharti Group-owned Airtel once again termed the equipment made by the state-run company and deployed by Bharat Sanchar Nigam Ltd (BSNL), are "sub-standard" Airtle also dismissed the local equipment maker's clarification.

Article Title: Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman says ‘Superintelligence can be the best invention ever’ but there’s a condition
Article Text:
ASI should be an 'Anti-Goal': Suleyman

Satya Nadella Steps Back to Focus on AI: Microsoft’s Major Reorganisation Explained





Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman has again issued a warning about the future of artificial intelligence (AI), saying that superintelligence can be humanity's greatest breakthrough, but only if it prioritises human interests above all else. “Superintelligence could be the best invention ever – but only if it puts the interests of humans above everything else,” Suleyman wrote on X, framing the challenge facing AI researchers as they race toward increasingly powerful systems.Suleyman’s latest warning comes days after he spoke on an episode of the Silicon Valley Girl Podcast, urging researchers to treat artificial superintelligence (ASI), which is nothing but an AI with reasoning capabilities far exceeding human capacity, as an “anti-goal” rather than a development target.“It doesn't feel like a positive vision of the future. It would be very hard to contain something like that or align it to our values,” Suleyman said of ASI, citing the immense risks of controlling such technology.Suleyman also revealed his team is pursuing what he calls “humanist superintelligence” – advanced AI designed explicitly to support and prioritise human interests rather than operate as an independent superintelligent entity.Microsoft’s AI CEO also pushed back against speculation about AI consciousness. He warned researchers saying that simulation and genuine consciousness or granting AI systems moral status must be avoided.“These things don't suffer. They don't feel pain. They're just simulating high-quality conversation,” he explained. Earlier this month, Suleyman went further, advising developers to abandon research exploring AI consciousness altogether. He argued that consciousness remains an exclusively biological trait and that pursuing it in artificial systems is fundamentally misguided.“I don't think that is work that people should be doing. If you ask the wrong question, you end up with the wrong answer. I think it's totally the wrong question,” Suleyman stated.
Article Summary: Mustafa Suleyman says superintelligence can be humanity's greatest breakthrough. But only if it prioritises human interests above all else, he says. He urges researchers to treat artificial superintelligence as an ‘anti-goal’ rather than a development target.

Article Title: Two 15-year-old kids challenge Australia’s social media ban for teens: ‘robs young Australians of…’
Article Text:
‘Like Orwell's 1984, and its scares me’

What the Australian government has to say





Two Australian teenagers have launched a constitutional challenge against the social media ban for under-16s, filing their case in the High Court of Australia, which is the nation's highest court, just two weeks before the law takes effect. Noah Jones and Macy Neyland, both 15, are serving as plaintiffs in proceedings initiated by the Digital Freedom Project at the court. According to a report by news agency Reuters, the campaign group filed the challenge on Wednesday (November 26), seeking to block legislation.The law will force social media platforms, including YouTube , TikTok, Snapchat, and Meta-owned Facebook as well as Instagram to deactivate more than one million accounts held by Australian teenagers when the ban begins December 10.The Digital Freedom Project argues the ban violates young Australians' freedom of political communication—an implied constitutional right in a country without express free speech protections. “The legislation is grossly excessive,” the group was quoted as saying. It also claimed that it “robs” minors of fundamental rights.Neyland said that the law would silence youth voices on critical issues.“Young people like me are the voters of tomorrow... we shouldn't be silenced.It's like Orwell's book 1984, and that scares me,” she said.Communications Minister Anika Wells dismissed the legal challenge shortly after it was announced, telling Parliament that the government will not back down.“Despite the fact that we are receiving threats and legal challenges by people with ulterior motives, the Albanese Labor government remains steadfastly on the side of parents, and not of platforms,” Wells said.The teenagers aren't the only ones preparing legal action. Australian media reports indicate YouTube has also threatened a High Court challenge, arguing the ban unconstitutionally burdens political communication.The ban was passed into law in November 2024, and is said to represent one of the world’s most comprehensive attempts to regulate minors' social media access. Tech companies face steep penalties for non-compliance: up to A$49.5 million ($32.22 million) in fines.
Article Summary: Two Australian teenagers have launched a constitutional challenge against the social media ban for under-16s. Noah Jones and Macy Neyland, both 15, are serving as plaintiffs in proceedings initiated by the Digital Freedom Project. The law will force social media platforms, including YouTube, TikTok, Snapchat, and Meta-owned Facebook as well as Instagram to deactivate more than one million accounts held by Australian teenagers.

Why Larry Page is richer than Sergey Brin

Google-parent company Alphabet’s sudden rise in stock has triggered a major shakeup in the world’s richest rankings. Notably, Google co-founder, Sergey Brin , has also moved up, overtaking Amazon’s Jeff Bezos , according to Forbes Real-Time Billionaires List. Sergey Brin also climbed the list, passing Jeff Bezos ($241.5 billion) to become the world’s fourth-richest person with an estimated net worth of $245.6 billion.While Page and Brin co-founded Google and hold a combined 87.9% of Alphabet’s Class B (10-votes per share) stock, Page holds significantly more shares (389 million) than Brin (362.7 million). According to Forbes, the gap in equity is attributed to Brin’s philanthropic activity.According to Securities and Exchange Commission filings, Brin actively sold his stake and made donations of his Alphabet and Tesla stock to nonprofit groups and Parkinson's research. He donated $700 million earlier this year, and in 2023, he gave away $615 million and $600 million.This comes as Alphabet is nearing a $4 trillion market capitalisation, after breaching the $3 trillion threshold in September this year. A victory in the Google Chrome case, coupled with Google Gemini 3.0 and Nano Banana Pro AI image generation model boosted the company's valuation in the last three months.Moreover, the news about Meta in talks with Google to use its Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) for training AI models has also pushed its market cap by 250 billion in a day.
